alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. You know, I've been trying to be very miserly in the kitchen to economize and so forth. We're trying this way and when I do peas, like in spring, like this, then I try to use the pad occasionally to do a soup with it. You can see the inside of the pad here, and if you break it, there is a kind of flesh here, and it's quite sweet, actually. And so we use that in a soup. Of course, you have to strain it. I strain it with a food mill, because there is a lot of fiber in it. I have 4 cups of water here. And it can be water, chicken stock, or water. And I put about 2 teaspoons of chicken bouillon, or chicken base here. I have a pound of potato here, the potato, so about 4 cups, you know. And my pound of peas. This is 1 pound of peas. And that pound of peas usually will give me about half of it will be the peas, about 7, 8 ounces. And the rest will be the part, same size, about the same amount. And I'll put maybe Some onion in there. Yeah, a thing of onion. Maybe 3 quarter of a cup to a cup of onion. Okay. The salt, it depend on the, still need a little bit of salt, but it depends on your stock. We bring that to a very strong boil. I cover it and I cook it 30 minutes. Then we'll go on to strain it and finish it up. Okay, now it comes to a strong boil. I'm going to cover it, lower the heat and 30 minutes. As you can see, the pot are really green here. After 30 minutes, they'll turn a slightly darker color. My pea soup is cooked. As you can see now, the pods have changed color. And of course, they are very fibrous. So this, what I want to do first, I usually, I put that directly in the food processor like this, you know, at least the pad. I think I have all of it here. Maybe a little bit of the liquid. I'll put that through the food mill here. Or if you don't have a food mill, through a strainer, it's a little bit more work. See that the food mill, this way you have your leg here, that you do. Make sure that you put that the right way. I mean, to people who put it this way, no, it goes this way. And I used to use that certainly a great deal before the advance of the food processor. You know, we use that all the time. Okay, put half of it maybe. Come back up the other way, a few times this way. Well, you can see here a lot of fiber. So clean up the bottom of the pan, clean up of this. Okay, so I remove most of the fiber in there, the rest of it. Rinse it with a little bit of the stock here. Now I can really just put it in there. Delicious taste of peas. Remember I have no oil, I have no butter, I have nothing in it. So I'm going to finish it with about a third of a cup of cream. And as you can see here, I have a close to 1 and a half quarter of soup and even with a third or even half a cup of cream is less than 1 tablespoon per person. So enough soup, I would say for 6 at least here. Nice portion of soup like that. The peas taste wonderful. Maybe a little bit of char-siu for color on top. And this is it, my peapod soup. Happy cooking. Thank you.

paragraphs.transcript:
Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. You know, I've been trying to be very miserly in the kitchen to economize and so forth. We're trying this way and when I do peas, like in spring, like this, then I try to use the pad occasionally to do a soup with it. You can see the inside of the pad here, and if you break it, there is a kind of flesh here, and it's quite sweet, actually. And so we use that in a soup.

Of course, you have to strain it. I strain it with a food mill, because there is a lot of fiber in it. I have 4 cups of water here. And it can be water, chicken stock, or water. And I put about 2 teaspoons of chicken bouillon, or chicken base here.

I have a pound of potato here, the potato, so about 4 cups, you know. And my pound of peas. This is 1 pound of peas. And that pound of peas usually will give me about half of it will be the peas, about 7, 8 ounces. And the rest will be the part, same size, about the same amount.

And I'll put maybe Some onion in there. Yeah, a thing of onion. Maybe 3 quarter of a cup to a cup of onion. Okay. The salt, it depend on the, still need a little bit of salt, but it depends on your stock.

We bring that to a very strong boil. I cover it and I cook it 30 minutes. Then we'll go on to strain it and finish it up. Okay, now it comes to a strong boil. I'm going to cover it, lower the heat and 30 minutes.

As you can see, the pot are really green here. After 30 minutes, they'll turn a slightly darker color. My pea soup is cooked. As you can see now, the pods have changed color. And of course, they are very fibrous.

So this, what I want to do first, I usually, I put that directly in the food processor like this, you know, at least the pad. I think I have all of it here. Maybe a little bit of the liquid. I'll put that through the food mill here. Or if you don't have a food mill, through a strainer, it's a little bit more work.

See that the food mill, this way you have your leg here, that you do. Make sure that you put that the right way. I mean, to people who put it this way, no, it goes this way. And I used to use that certainly a great deal before the advance of the food processor. You know, we use that all the time.

Okay, put half of it maybe. Come back up the other way, a few times this way. Well, you can see here a lot of fiber. So clean up the bottom of the pan, clean up of this. Okay, so I remove most of the fiber in there, the rest of it.

Rinse it with a little bit of the stock here. Now I can really just put it in there. Delicious taste of peas. Remember I have no oil, I have no butter, I have nothing in it. So I'm going to finish it with about a third of a cup of cream.

And as you can see here, I have a close to 1 and a half quarter of soup and even with a third or even half a cup of cream is less than 1 tablespoon per person. So enough soup, I would say for 6 at least here. Nice portion of soup like that. The peas taste wonderful. Maybe a little bit of char-siu for color on top.

And this is it, my peapod soup. Happy cooking. Thank you.

sentences.text: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home.
You know, I've been trying to be very miserly in the kitchen to economize and so forth.
We're trying this way and when I do peas, like in spring, like this, then I try to use the pad occasionally to do a soup with it.
You can see the inside of the pad here, and if you break it, there is a kind of flesh here, and it's quite sweet, actually.
And so we use that in a soup.
Of course, you have to strain it.
I strain it with a food mill, because there is a lot of fiber in it.
I have 4 cups of water here.
And it can be water, chicken stock, or water.
And I put about 2 teaspoons of chicken bouillon, or chicken base here.
I have a pound of potato here, the potato, so about 4 cups, you know.
And my pound of peas.
This is 1 pound of peas.
And that pound of peas usually will give me about half of it will be the peas, about 7, 8 ounces.
And the rest will be the part, same size, about the same amount.
And I'll put maybe Some onion in there.
Yeah, a thing of onion.
Maybe 3 quarter of a cup to a cup of onion.
Okay.
The salt, it depend on the, still need a little bit of salt, but it depends on your stock.
We bring that to a very strong boil.
I cover it and I cook it 30 minutes.
Then we'll go on to strain it and finish it up.
Okay, now it comes to a strong boil.
I'm going to cover it, lower the heat and 30 minutes.
As you can see, the pot are really green here.
After 30 minutes, they'll turn a slightly darker color.
My pea soup is cooked.
As you can see now, the pods have changed color.
And of course, they are very fibrous.
So this, what I want to do first, I usually, I put that directly in the food processor like this, you know, at least the pad.
I think I have all of it here.
Maybe a little bit of the liquid.
I'll put that through the food mill here.
Or if you don't have a food mill, through a strainer, it's a little bit more work.
See that the food mill, this way you have your leg here, that you do.
Make sure that you put that the right way.
I mean, to people who put it this way, no, it goes this way.
And I used to use that certainly a great deal before the advance of the food processor.
You know, we use that all the time.
Okay, put half of it maybe.
Come back up the other way, a few times this way.
Well, you can see here a lot of fiber.
So clean up the bottom of the pan, clean up of this.
Okay, so I remove most of the fiber in there, the rest of it.
Rinse it with a little bit of the stock here.
Now I can really just put it in there.
Delicious taste of peas.
Remember I have no oil, I have no butter, I have nothing in it.
So I'm going to finish it with about a third of a cup of cream.
And as you can see here, I have a close to 1 and a half quarter of soup and even with a third or even half a cup of cream is less than 1 tablespoon per person.
So enough soup, I would say for 6 at least here.
Nice portion of soup like that.
The peas taste wonderful.
Maybe a little bit of char-siu for color on top.
And this is it, my peapod soup.
Happy cooking.
Thank you.
